contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced|type=animal|date=December 2009}} {{italic title}} {{Taxobox |name = ''Xanioascus canadensis'' |image = Xanioascus_canadensis.jpg |image_caption = Artist's reconstruction |fossil range ={{fossilrange|515|505}} |regnum = [[Animal]]ia |phylum = [[Ctenophora]] |genus = '''''Xanioascus''''' |species = '''''X. canadensis''''' |binomial = ''Xanioascus canadensis'' }} '''''Xanioascus canadensis''''' is an extinct [[ctenophora|ctenophore]], known from the Canadian [[Burgess Shale]] in [[British Columbia]]. The species which is about 515 to 505 million years old had 24 comb rows - in contrast to all modern forms which have only 8. Other important Cambrian ctenophore fossils are ''[[Fasciculus vesanus]]'' and ''[[Ctenorhabdotus capulus]]''. ==See also== *''[[Ctenorhabdotus capulus]]'' *''[[Fasciculus vesanus]]'' <!--*[[Maotianshan shales]] ctenophores **''[[Maotianoascus octonarius]]'' **''[[Sinoascus paillatus]]'' **''[[Stromatoveris psygmoglena]]'' --> == External links == * {{Burgess Shale species | 134}} [[Category:Burgess Shale fossils]] [[Category:Fossil Ctenophores]] {{cambrian-stub}} {{Ctenophore-stub}}
